question: Question_C_01
statement:
Suppose \emph{$f$(x)} satisfies the equation \emph{ln($f$(x)) = x ln(x)}.
Express \emph{$f$'(x)} in terms of \emph{x} only (i.e. do not leave
\emph{$f$(x)} in the expression).
sols:
First we will solve for $\displaystyle f'(x)$ using the chain rule on
the left and the product rule on the right.

$\frac{1}{f(x)} f'(x) = \ln(x) + x \frac1x$

$\displaystyle f'(x) = (\ln(x) + 1)f(x)$

In order to complete the question, we must solve for $f(x)$ in terms of
\emph{x}. We will do this by using the equation

\[\displaystyle
\ln(f(x)) = x\ln(x)\]

a second time, together with the log rule $a \ln(b) = \ln(b^a)$. So we
can rewrite the right side of the the equation above as:

$\displaystyle \ln(f(x)) = \ln(x^x)$

Applying the exponential function to both sides causes the logarithm to
disappear, leaving:

$e^{\ln(f(x))} = e^{\ln(x^x)}$

$\displaystyle f(x) = x^x$

Substituting this into our derivative, we arrive at the final answer:

$\displaystyle f'(x) = (\ln(x) + 1)(x^x)$
hints:
To solve for $\displaystyle f'(x)$, use the chain rule and the product
rule on the equation

\[\displaystyle
\ln(f(x)) = x\ln(x)\]

You will find an equation for $\displaystyle f'(x)$ that still depends
on $\displaystyle f(x)$. To express $\displaystyle f(x)$ with respect to
\emph{x} only, use

\[\displaystyle
\ln(f(x)) = x\ln(x)\]

a second time.
